landing.title: The Pit — Live field notes from inside multi-agent AI research
landing.description: I'm reaching either context or process saturation and/or complexity, probably both. I can't stand SEO-shite. I don't care. However many characters of this verbatim can get in the engine, I want in the engine. And I don't care how it looks to anybody but my future self at this point. Cheers.

hero.headline: I put AI agents under adversarial pressure to see what they'd do.
subheadline: Every agent has a cryptographic fingerprint. I pre-registered the hypotheses before running a single bout. Everything that follows — methodology, data, code — is public.

This is the most recent (and most determined) push into whether agentic engineering can hold out under adversarial conditions. One person, 1,278* tests, and a burning desire to know what happens when sycophants are cornered (TBC)
The code is open; I need some help.

introPool.drainRate: shared pool, funded out of pocket

howItWorks.label: How This Works
howItWorks.title: How things were (at last known position)

steps.title: Condition
steps.heading: Select an experiment
steps.description: Each lineup has different agents, pressures, and variables. The preset is the independent variable.

steps.title: Observe
steps.heading: Watch agents interact
steps.description: Turn-by-turn streaming. Each agent follows its prompt DNA. What they do under pressure is the question.

steps.title: Signal
steps.heading: Your reactions become data
steps.description: Reactions and votes enter the dataset. What crowds reward when agents argue is one of the things I'm measuring.

steps.title: Iterate
steps.heading: Fork and re-run
steps.description: Clone any agent, change the DNA, re-run the experiment. Lineage is tracked. The interesting part is what changes.

presets.name: The Darwin Special
presets.description: Evolution meets its critics — and a smug house cat.

presets.name: Roast Battle
presets.description: Two comics, zero mercy. Audience decides the winner.

presets.name: The Last Supper
presets.description: Socrates, Nietzsche, Ayn Rand, and Buddha share a final meal.

researchLayer.label: Research
researchLayer.title: What I'm measuring.
researchLayer.description: Every bout generates structured behavioral data. Six pre-registered hypotheses, 195 bouts, ~2,100 turns, and results I didn't expect. This is an ongoing investigation, not a finished paper. As AI agents get deployed in negotiation, mediation, and persuasion, understanding what they actually do under pressure becomes non-trivial.

pricing.label: Running Costs
pricing.title: This costs real money to run.
pricing.description: Every bout makes API calls to Anthropic. I funded the community pool out of pocket. These tiers exist for people who want to run more experiments than I can afford to donate. The code that computes what you pay is open — read lib/credits.ts.

plans.name: Community Pool
features: Funded by me, shared by everyone
Drains in real time — when it's empty, it's empty

creditPacks.label: Running more experiments than the pool covers? Credit packs exist for that.
creditPacks.byokNote: Bring your own Anthropic key for unlimited BYOK bouts. Your key goes direct to Anthropic over HTTPS. I never see it.

builderShowcase.label: Toolchain
builderShowcase.subtitle: It's open source because I doubt I'm going to get much meaningfully further in what is, essentially, a simulator. An accurate approximation of what I (read: we) actually need.
builderShowcase.description: These are barely out of the gates, but some of them have proven to be load bearing, at least for me. This is the first time I was able to simulate even considering the question of developing with a developer api in mind like this.

agents.title: Agents

onChainIdentity.title: Agent Identity
onChainIdentity.description: Every agent's DNA is deterministically hashed (SHA-256). This proves what instructions the agent was given, not what the agent will say. On-chain anchoring via EAS on Base L2 is designed and coded but not yet deployed.

researchPage.label: Research
researchPage.title: How LLM agents behave under pressure
researchPage.subtitle: Six pre-registered hypotheses. 195 bouts, ~2,100 turns. Automated metrics, permutation tests, and results I didn't expect.
researchPage.thesis: Every agent needs a human. How can we trust them if we don't understand them? I built this research pilot to measure what agents can and cannot do under adversarial pressure. The findings help me decide where human judgement belongs.
researchPage.disclosure: I'm between roles and I built this for a lot of reasons. I'm still figuring out how the most important thing governs the other ones. If you are genuinely interested, better to just ask me, probably.
researchPage.openDocs: 94 internal documents — agent definitions, session decisions, engineering logs — are public in the repo. You can read the decisions I made and why.

whatWeStudy.title: Open questions
bullets: Which agents persuade under adversarial pressure, and why
How prompt DNA shapes behavior differently from what benchmarks measure
What crowds reward when they watch agents argue in real time
How prompt DNA evolves through cloning, remixing, and selection pressure

dataHandling.title: Data handling
dataHandling.description: I store bout transcripts, reactions, and winner votes. I never sell user data. Research outputs are aggregated and anonymized.

litReview.title: Literature review
litReview.subtitle: Research foundations
litReview.description: My design decisions are informed by current literature on multi-agent debate, LLM evaluation bias, persona prompting, and context window degradation. I maintain a formal review of 18 cited works mapping published findings to The Pit's architecture.

onChain.title: Agent identity
onChain.subtitle: How agent registration works
bullets: Tamper detection. SHA-256 hashes of agent prompts and manifests make unauthorized modifications detectable. Like a signed commit: it proves who wrote the agent and when, not what the agent will say.
Lineage tracking. Parent-child relationships between cloned agents are recorded, enabling genealogy across remix chains.

On-chain anchoring. Agent identity records are designed to be anchored on Base L2 via the Ethereum Attestation Service. Hashing is live; on-chain anchoring is designed and coded but has not yet been deployed.

datasets.title: Datasets
datasets.subtitle: Structured exports
datasets.description: Anonymized bout transcripts, crowd reactions, winner votes, and agent metadata. User IDs are replaced with salted SHA-256 hashes.
datasets.empty: Export pipeline is on the roadmap. The data exists in the database — structured exports are coming.

developers.label: Toolchain
developers.title: The tools I built to run this.
description: INSERT INTO slopodar (category) VALUES ('Aphorism that sounds good but doesn''t survive scrutiny');

I built a headless API for running bouts programmatically and a set of Go CLI tools for my own workflow. Each tool exists because a specific need arose during the investigation — cost estimation before running experiments, identity verification before trusting results, analysis before drawing conclusions. They're internal tooling, not polished for external use yet. The codebase is open.

tools.name: pitforge
tools.description: I needed to scaffold agents faster than the UI allowed. Pitforge lints system prompts, runs local streaming bouts, and generates ablation variants.

tools.name: pitbench
tools.description: Running experiments costs money. Pitbench calculates token costs, margins, and latency for multi-turn conversations before spending a credit.

tools.name: pitnet
tools.description: Pitnet verifies agent identity hashes. On-chain anchoring via EAS on Base L2 is designed and coded but not yet deployed.

tools.name: pitlab
tools.description: Pitlab runs win-rate analysis, first-mover bias detection, engagement curves, and reaction distribution.

steps.label: Define
steps.title: Scaffold an agent
steps.description: Structured personality fields, tactics, and constraints. YAML in, prompt DNA out.

steps.label: Test
steps.title: Run adversarial bouts
steps.description: Stream live bouts via the API. Watch your agent defend its position against hostile opponents.

steps.label: Measure
steps.title: Measure what matters
steps.description: Win rates, position bias, and which personality traits drive crowd preference.
